Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Rose-Hulman Undergraduate Research Experience in Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rose-Hulman's summer REU program in mathematics has served over 150 undergraduates in the past 21 years. This REU has introduced students to problems in group theory, "cwatsets", hyperbolic geometry, number theory, inverse problems, and geometric analysis, and made contributions to each of these areas. The program has evolved from a single faculty member to one involving enthusiastic mentors who rotate in and out of the program year-to-year. The result is a wider range of problems for undergraduates to investigate. The REU has also gained strong support from the mathematics department as a whole and the Rose-Hulman community.

Though the mathematical topics we investigate are diverse, we have developed a coherent approach to the research: we initially make use of computational tools to help students understand the problems at hand, by working out specific cases and examples. They can then begin making general conjectures, designing algorithms, and follow up with large scale computational and/or statistical investigations (as appropriate) and eventually rigorous analysis and proofs. The problems we pose can be attacked by students with a fairly modest mathematical background. However, the problems are drawn from active areas of mathematics, and can quickly lead to the frontiers of current research, depending on the student's abilities and drive. Our REU develops the students as "complete" mathematicians, capable of independent thinking, making and proving conjectures, and communicating their results. In the process, we hope to give them a basis for future career decisions. Thus, in the selection process we are especially interested in students who, beyond having adequate preparation, express interest in a career involving research, but who may not otherwise have a chance at an undergraduate research opportunity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of our Research Experiences for Undergraduates program
is to give undergraduate students the chance to participate in the
type of mathematical research that is often not experienced until
graduate school.  We hope that the students will use this experience
to make more informed judgments about their future career paths.
Eleven students per year were introduced to mathematical research in
the areas of computational number theory, systems biology, inverse
problems, geometric analysis, and delay differential equations.  This
includes training in literature search, reading advanced mathematics,
experimental mathematics (conjecture and testing of conjecture through
numerical experiments), development of mathematical models and
algorithms to solve mathematical problems, and both written and oral
mathematical exposition.  Students in most cases worked
collaboratively to gain better understanding of their specific
problems and to emphasize the modern form of mathematical research as
a team effort with each individual contributing to the end result.  A
brief synopsis of each group's area of research is described below.

 
The Computational Number Theory group studied mathematics related to
certain types of "digital signatures" used on the Internet and in many
other modern computer systems.  These signatures are designed so that
each one is unique to a specific combination of signer and document,
and cannot be forged by any other party.  Nevertheless, anyone can use
public information to verify the authenticity of the signature without
jeopardizing its security.  This process relies on the existence of
mathematical transformations which are easy to perform in one
direction, but cannot be reversed without secret private information.
In most cases, however, it is an unproven conjecture that the
transformations are as hard to invert as we think.  We investigated
certain of these mathematical transformations and gathered evidence
which suggests that in most cases the conjecture holds.  However, we
also uncovered some statistical anomalies that it might be possible to
exploit in the future.

Students working on the projects in Systems Biology combined the
mathematical and computational sciences to model, solve, and analyze
modern problems in biology.  One project studied a mathematical model
to discern if two proteins had similar roles within a cell.  This is
an increasingly important problem as the number of known protein
structures grows. A second project studied and improved a mathematical
model of a cell's metabolism.  The associated computational work
proved a heightened efficacy of the new model over its predecessor. A
third project investigated estimates of the genetic diversity required
by a previous population so that it could combine to create a current
population.

The Inverse Problems group focused on the ideas of non-destructive
testing and cloaking.  The goal of non-destructive testing is to image
the interior of an object without causing damage. A classic example is
the use of x-rays, but other methods can be more useful in certain
situations.  Two techniques of recent interest employ electrical
and/or thermal methods, so-called "impedance" and "thermal" imaging.
Groups of students mathematically modeled these techniques and
explored the theoretical potential of each to produce images of the
interior of an object.  An allied area of current interest is that of
"cloaking," in which one attempts to hide an object from an observer.
